questions.text: A 26-year-old G2P1 woman at 34 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department with complaints of bleeding. Her heart rate is 100/min and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. She denies having abdominal pain. Upon examination the uterus is relaxed. TVS was done which reveals placenta away from OS but few vessels are seen running above cervical OS, and the fetal heart tracing is non reassuring revealing sinusoidal pattern. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The key features pointing to vasa previa include:
    1. Painless vaginal bleeding
    2. No uterine tenderness (uterus relaxed)
    3. Fetal distress with sinusoidal heart pattern, often due to fetal blood loss
    4. Transvaginal ultrasound showing fetal vessels over the internal os (Option C is correct)

Explanation of other options:

Placenta previa (Option A): Also causes painless bleeding, but no vessels crossing the OS would be seen on TVS

Placental abruption (Option B): Presents with painful bleeding, uterine tenderness, and tense uterus

Excessive show (Option D): Refers to mucous-streaked bleeding near labour onset; not associated with fetal distress or visible fetal vessels

Key Takeaways:

  • Vasa previa = fetal vessels over internal os + painless bleeding + fetal distress
  • Requires immediate cesarean delivery
  • Sinusoidal pattern is indicative of fetal anemia or hypoxia

questions.text: Sinusoidal heart rate pattern is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sinusoidal heart rate pattern is a smooth, wave-like, regular oscillation of the fetal heart baseline, typically indicating severe fetal anemia, commonly due to fetal hemorrhage in cases like vasa previa.

Explanation of other options:

Placenta previa (Option A): Causes maternal bleeding, not fetal blood loss; rarely associated with sinusoidal pattern

Battledore placenta (Option C): Marginal cord insertion; usually incidental and not associated with fetal anemia

Succenturiate placenta (Option D): Accessory lobe increases risk of retained placenta but not fetal anemia or sinusoidal pattern

Key Takeaways:

  • Sinusoidal pattern strongly suggests fetal anemia, often from vasa previa rupture
  • Requires urgent cesarean delivery
  • Differentiated from other placental anomalies by fetal vessel involvement

questions.text: Immediate cord ligation is done in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Immediate cord ligation is performed to reduce placental transfusion in conditions where it may be harmful to the newborn, such as:
    • Preterm babies: To prevent polycythemia and intraventricular hemorrhage from sudden blood volume shift
    • Rh incompatibility: To limit fetal exposure to maternal antibodies in residual placental blood

Key Takeaways:

  • Immediate cord clamping is indicated in preterm deliveries and Rh isoimmunization
  • Aimed at protecting the newborn from adverse volume or antibody effects
  • Delayed clamping is standard in other scenarios to improve iron stores

questions.text: In intrauterine death with transverse lie, the following are treatment options except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Craniotomy is contraindicated in transverse lie because the fetal head is not the presenting part, making the procedure anatomically impossible (Option C eliminated)

In case of intrauterine death, the possible management can be:

  • Decapitation: Used when the neck is accessible, especially in neglected shoulder presentations in IUFD (Option A eliminated)
  • Evisceration: Performed when thoracic or abdominal contents present first, to reduce fetal bulk for easier vaginal delivery (Option B eliminated)
  • Cesarean section: Reserved for cases where vaginal destructive delivery is not possible, such as in primigravida, scarred uterus, or inaccessible fetal parts (Option D eliminated)
  • Internal podalic version with breech extraction: Possible when fetal lower limbs are accessible and uterine conditions permit
  • Foetal decapitation under anesthesia: Considered if internal version fails or is unfeasible
  • Symphysiotomy: Rare and historical; only considered when cesarean is not an option due to lack of surgical access

Key Takeaways:

  • Craniotomy is specific to cephalic presentations and has no role in transverse lie
  • Destructive procedures like decapitation or evisceration are appropriate for IUFD with transverse lie
  • Cesarean section remains the safest option when vaginal delivery is unsafe or technically impossible

choices.text: Wait and watch for progress of labor

questions.text: When in labor, a diagnosis of occipito posterior presentation is made. The most appropriate management would be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Occipito-posterior (OP) position often resolves spontaneously as labour progresses, especially in multiparous women. Therefore, initial management is expectant, observing for rotation and descent
  • Emergency CS is only indicated if there is failure of descent, arrest of rotation, or fetal/maternal distress(Option A eliminated)
  • Early rupture of membranes is avoided as it may increase risk of cord prolapse and reduce the cushioning effect, worsening malrotation (Option C eliminated)
  • Oxytocin drip is started only if uterine contractions are inadequate, not routinely for OP position (Option D eliminated)

Clinical features of OP position:

  • Per abdomen (P/A):
    • Subumbilical flattening
    • Fetal limbs easily palpable anteriorly
    • Fetal heart sounds best heard at the flanks
  • Per vaginum (P/V):
    • Anterior fontanelle felt more easily than usual
    • Posterior fontanelle directed toward the sacroiliac joint

Key Takeaways:

  • OP position often resolves with expectant management
  • Recognized clinically by subumbilical flattening, limbs in front, and fontanelle orientation
  • Intervene only when labour fails to progress

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't favor face presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Placenta praevia obstructs the lower uterine segment, preventing engagement of the presenting part, and is not associated with face presentation
  • Anencephaly leads to loss of cranial vault support, resulting in extreme extension of the fetal head, favoring face presentation (Option A eliminated)
  • Contracted pelvis may prevent proper flexion of the fetal head, causing it to extend, leading to face presentation (Option B eliminated)
  • Thyroid swelling (fetal goitre) can interfere with normal flexion and promote extension of the fetal head (Option D eliminated)

Key Takeaways:

  • Face presentation results from hyperextension of the fetal head
  • Conditions that prevent flexion or encourage extension favor face presentation
  • Placenta praevia affects presentation type by mechanical obstruction, not fetal head position

questions.text: On per vaginal examination, anterior fontanelle and supraorbital ridge is felt in the second stage of labour. The presentation is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Feeling the anterior fontanelle along with the supraorbital ridge per vaginam indicates that the fetal head is in partial extension, characteristic of brow presentation.
  • Deflexed head presents the anterior fontanelle but not supraorbital ridge; typically associated with military attitude (Option B eliminated)
  • Flexed head presents the posterior fontanelle, with minimal palpation of anterior fontanelle or facial bones (Option C eliminated)
  • Face presentation occurs with complete extension, and mouth, nose, malar bones are felt-not the anterior fontanelle (Option D eliminated)

Key Takeaways:

  • Brow presentation = anterior fontanelle + supraorbital ridge palpable
  • Indicates partial extension of fetal head
  • Unstable lie, often converts to face or vertex during labour

questions.text: In a case of direct occipitoposterior position (face to pubis delivery) most commonly encountered problem is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In direct occipitoposterior (OP) position, the fetal head delivers with the face toward the pubic symphysis (face-to-pubis), requiring maximum perineal distension
  • This leads to a high risk of complete perineal tears involving the vaginal wall, perineal body, and anal sphincter complex.
  • Intracranial injury is rare and not specific to OP deliveries (Option A eliminated)
  • Cephalhematoma occurs due to pressure over parietal bones, more common in instrumental or prolonged labours, not specific to OP (Option B eliminated)
  • Paraurethral tears may occur, but they are less severe and not the most common complication in face-to-pubis delivery (Option C eliminated)

Key Takeaways:

  • Face-to-pubis delivery stretches the perineum maximally
  • Complete perineal tears are the most common and serious complication
  • Careful perineal support and episiotomy may help reduce tear severity

questions.text: 37 weeks presents with transverse presentation, Treatment of Choice is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lower Segment Cesarean Section (LSCS) is the definitive treatment in cases of transverse lie at 37 weeks, particularly if labour has commenced, as vaginal delivery is generally contraindicated in such presentations (Option C is correct)
  • External Cephalic Version (ECV) may be considered prior to the onset of labour or in early labour under the following conditions:
    1. Adequate amniotic fluid volume
    2. Intact membranes
    3. Appropriate fetal size for gestational age
    4. No contraindications to vaginal delivery
    5. Patient not in active labour
    6. ECV is recommended in all suitable candidates to convert the lie to cephalic and potentially avoid cesarean delivery
  • LSCS is indicated when:
    1. ECV is unsuccessful
    2. ECV is contraindicated
    3. Labour has already begun
    4. There are other obstetric complications necessitating cesarean delivery
  • Active labour in a woman with a transverse lie constitutes an absolute indication for cesarean section
  • Management in late labour:
    1. If the fetus is alive and viable, LSCS is strongly preferred
    2. If the fetus is deceased:
      1. LSCS remains safer, especially for practitioners not trained in destructive procedures
      2. If a destructive operation (e.g., decapitation) is performed, postoperative uterine exploration is mandatory to rule out uterine rupture

Explanation of other options:

Allowing for cervical dilatation (Option A): Inappropriate and hazardous in the context of transverse lie; increases the risk of cord prolapse and uterine rupture

Internal podalic version (Option B): Limited to specific scenarios such as second twin or intrauterine fetal demise; not appropriate for a singleton viable fetus at term

Forceps delivery (Option D): Applicable only in cephalic presentations and thus not feasible in a transverse lie

Key Takeaways:

  • LSCS is the standard of care for transverse lie at term, particularly once labour has started
  • ECV may be attempted before labour in well-selected cases
  • Destructive procedures are reserved for IUFD and should only be performed by trained specialists
  • Uterine exploration is essential following destructive delivery to exclude complications

questions.text: A 30 years old multigravida presented with transverse lie with hand prolapse in IInd stage of labour with dead fetus. The treatment is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  1. Cesarean section is the treatment of choice in a multigravida in the second stage of labour with transverse lie, hand prolapse, and a dead fetus, because:
    1. Labour is advanced, increasing the risk of uterine rupture
    2. Maternal safety takes precedence, and LSCS is safer than destructive procedures in most modern clinical settings
    3. Though destructive operations may be technically feasible, they require specialist training and appropriate instruments, which are often not available or advisable in standard obstetric care

Explanation of other options:

Craniotomy (Option B): Indicated in cephalic presentation; not applicable in transverse lie

Decapitation (Option C): May be considered if the neck is accessible and expertise is available, but LSCS is generally preferred

Cleidotomy (Option D): Specifically used for shoulder dystocia; not suitable in transverse lie with hand prolapse

Key Takeaways:

  • In IUFD with transverse lie in second stage, either decapitation or LSCS may be viable
  • LSCS is generally preferred, particularly when the operator lacks training in destructive procedures
  • Clinical decision depends on stage of labour, fetal status, and practitioner expertise

questions.text: The commonest cause of occipitoposterior position of fetal head during labour is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Android pelvis is the most common anatomical cause of occipitoposterior (OP) position during labour due to:
    1. A narrow anterior segment and funnel-shaped cavity, which limit anterior rotation of the occiput
    2. Fetal head often engages in a deflexed, posterior orientation and fails to rotate, leading to deep transverse arrest (Option D is correct)
  • Additional Associations:
    1. Android pelvis: Linked with OP position and deep transverse arrest
    2. Anthropoid pelvis: Associated with persistent OP position and face-to-pubis delivery

Explanation of other options:

Maternal obesity (Option A): May be associated with labour dystocia but not a direct cause of OP position

Deflexion of fetal head (Option B): Usually a result of malposition, not a primary cause

Multiparity (Option C): Affects uterine tone but does not predispose to OP position

Key Takeaways:

  • Pelvic shape is critical in determining fetal position and rotation
  • Android pelvis is most frequently linked with labour malpositions and arrests
  • Anthropoid pelvis may allow OP delivery but with increased risk of perineal trauma

questions.text: In brow presentation, presenting diameter (s) is/are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In brow presentation, the fetal head is in partial extension, causing the mentovertical diameter (14 cm) to present-the longest diameter of the fetal skull and non-negotiable through the pelvis.

Explanation of other options:

Submentovertical (Option A): Measures 11.5 cm, seen in face presentation with complete extension

Occipitofrontal (Option B): Measures 11.5-12 cm, seen in deflexed vertex presentation

Suboccipitobregmatic (Option D): Measures 9.5 cm, seen in complete flexion (vertex presentation)-most favorable for vaginal delivery

Key Takeaways:

  • Mentovertical (14 cm) is the longest fetal skull diameter, seen in brow presentation
  • Brow presentation is unstable and typically requires cesarean delivery
  • Flexion vs. extension determines the presenting diameter and feasibility of vaginal delivery

questions.text: The Incidence of cord prolapse is least in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Frank breech presentation poses the lowest risk of cord prolapse because the buttocks effectively occupy the pelvic inlet, preventing the cord from slipping past after membrane rupture
  • Cord prolapse occurs when the umbilical cord lies below the presenting part following rupture of membranes
  • In cord presentation, the cord is below the presenting part but membranes remain intact
  • In occult cord prolapse, the cord lies beside the presenting part and is not palpable per vaginum
  • On CTG, variable decelerations are a key indicator of cord compression

Explanation of other options:

Footling presentation (Option B): Highest risk of cord prolapse in breech types due to incomplete filling of the pelvis

Transverse lie (Option C): Very high risk due to absence of any presenting part in the pelvic inlet

Brow presentation (Option D): Increased risk due to partial extension of the head and poor engagement

Key Takeaways:

  • Frank breech fills the pelvic inlet well, minimizing cord prolapse risk
  • Footling breech and transverse lie are the highest risk scenarios
  • Variable decelerations on CTG suggest cord involvement

questions.text: The most common form of fetal traumatic injury incurred during breech extraction is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intracranial hemorrhage is the most common traumatic injury during breech extraction, especially in preterm infants, due to:

  • Sudden decompression of the after-coming head
  • Hyperextension or traction injuries
  • Difficulty delivering the head last

Explanation of other options:

Rupture of the liver (Option A): Rare and usually associated with direct abdominal trauma

Rupture of the spleen (Option B): Extremely rare in breech deliveries

Intra-adrenal hemorrhage (Option C): May occur in birth trauma, but far less frequent than intracranial bleeding in breech extractions

Key Takeaways:

  • Breech extraction carries highest risk for intracranial hemorrhage
  • Most injuries occur during delivery of the after-coming head
  • Careful handling and proper technique are essential to prevent trauma

questions.text: The complications of shoulder presentations are all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Shoulder dystocia is a complication seen in cephalic presentations, typically after the head has delivered and the shoulders become impacted. It is not associated with shoulder presentation, which occurs in transverse lie

Complications of shoulder presentation:

  • Cord prolapse
  • Tonic uterine contractions leading to obstructed labour
  • Rupture of the uterus
  • Dehydration due to prolonged obstructed labour
  • Ketoacidosis in prolonged labour with metabolic stress
  • Septicemia, hemorrhage, rupture uterus, shock, and peritonitis

Explanation of other options:

Fetal death (Option A): Can result from cord prolapse, prolonged labour, or uterine rupture

Uterine rupture (Option B): A known risk of neglected shoulder presentation in active labour

Obstructed labour (Option C): A common outcome when shoulder presentation persists without intervention

Key Takeaways:

  • Shoulder dystocia is exclusive to cephalic presentation
  • Shoulder presentation complications are serious and often life-threatening
  • Requires early recognition and cesarean delivery if persistent

choices.text: The diameter distending the vulval outlet is mentovertical

questions.text: The following are related to face presentation except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In face presentation, the fetal head is in complete extension, and the engaging and distending diameter is the submentobregmatic (9.5 cm). The mentovertical (14 cm) is not involved in face presentation-it is seen in brow presentation.

Additional details on face presentation:

  • Attitude: Complete extension of head; flexion of limbs, spine extended; occiput in contact with fetal back
  • Denominator: Mentum (chin)
  • Commonest position: Left Mentoanterior (LMA)
  • Common maternal cause: Platypelloid pelvis
  • Common fetal cause: Anencephaly
  • Engaging diameter: Submentobregmatic (9.5 cm) in full extension
  • Engagement is delayed due to wide mentum-biparietal distance (7 cm)
  • Mechanism of head delivery: By flexion (diameter delivered = 5 cm)

Management:

  • Vaginal delivery is possible in mentoanterior positions
  • In mentoposterior, adopt a wait-and-watch policy early in labour
  • If persistent mentoposterior, cesarean section is indicated

Explanation of other options:

The commonest position is LMA (Option A): True-Left Mentoanterior is the most frequent and most favorable for vaginal delivery

Engaging diameter is submentobregmatic (Option B): True-9.5 cm, the same as in vertex presentations with a well-flexed head

Attitude is complete extension (Option D): True-the occiput touches the fetal back, with complete head extension

Key Takeaways:

  • Mentovertical diameter belongs to brow presentation, not face
  • Face presentation = complete head extension, denominator = mentum
  • Mode of delivery depends on mentum position (anterior = vaginal; posterior = CS)

choices.text: Head is deep into the pelvic cavity
Sagittal suture lies in the bispinous diameter
There is no progress at least for 1 hour following full dilatation of the cervix
Delivery should be done by immediate caesarean section

questions.text: For the deep transverse arrest all are correct except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Deep transverse arrest occurs when the fetal head is deep in the pelvis, with the sagittal suture in the transverse (bispinous) diameter, and no descent for ≥1 hour after full cervical dilation (Options A, B, and C are correct)
  • Immediate cesarean section is not always required-instrumental delivery (forceps or vacuum) may be attempted if conditions are favorable.

Explanation of other options:

Head is deep into the pelvic cavity (Option A): True-fetal head is engaged but fails to rotate

Sagittal suture lies in the bispinous diameter (Option B): True-key feature of deep transverse arrest

No progress for at least 1 hour after full dilation (Option C): True-this defines the arrest

Key Takeaways:

  • Deep transverse arrest = failure of internal rotation with sagittal suture in transverse diameter
  • Instrumental delivery is preferred if criteria are met
  • Cesarean section is reserved for failed instrumental attempt or contraindications

questions.text: ECV is absolutely contraindicated in all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Primigravida is not an absolute contraindication for External Cephalic Version (ECV). Although success rates may be slightly lower than in multigravida women, ECV is still routinely attempted in eligible primigravida cases (Option A is correct)

Explanation of other options:

IUGR (Option B): Absolute contraindication due to compromised fetal reserve and risk of fetal distress

Placenta previa (Option C): Absolute contraindication because of potential for severe hemorrhage and placental separation

Septate uterus (Option D): Contraindicated as uterine anomaly limits space for fetal rotation and increases risk of complications

Key Takeaways:

  • ECV is allowed in primigravida if other conditions are favorable
  • Absolute contraindications include placenta previa, IUGR, uterine anomalies
  • Always ensure NST and ultrasound guidance before ECV

questions.text: AG2 P1L1 female at 34 weeks of gestation with breech presentation. Next step in management:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a 34-week pregnant woman with breech presentation, the next appropriate step is to wait and attempt External Cephalic Version (ECV) at 37 weeks, provided there are no contraindications

Explanation of other options:

Planned cesarean at 38 weeks (Option B): Reserved if ECV fails or is contraindicated

Immediate cesarean (Option C): Not indicated at 34 weeks with a stable fetus and no labour

Induction of labor (Option D): Contraindicated in breech presentation at this stage

Key Takeaways:

  • ECV is the next step for breech after 36-37 weeks in eligible women
  • Cesarean is considered only if ECV fails or is contraindicated
  • No intervention is needed at 34 weeks unless other complications arise
